title: Are human beings truly free? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kind of. We can make choices consciously. But thinking is a very calorie intensive process, and so our natural tendency is to think as little as possible. In truth, we kind of spend our lives on autopilot, repeating behaviors we have learned, producing the behavior when the correct environmental stimuli is present. Even when we do think, it’s usually not really about what we are doing in that moment, it’s about the future, the past, the theoretical. We think we are free. And we are often told we are free. But let’s look at a real life example: Everyone is free to decide if their organs are donated or not. Certain countries have an opt-in system, where you have to sign up, and other countries have an opt-out system, where you donate by default unless you ask for it not to happen.  The answer varies depending on how the question is asked.  When someone goes into a shop to buy a product, they are free to buy whatever they want. Or are they? The salesman exists to try and have them make a certain choice. There are price anchoring strategies  If the kids are free to ask for candy any time they want, why does it matter so much to try and place it in front of their face at the checkout? Everyone thinks advertising doesn’t impact them, only everyone else, and yet advertising is a trillion dollar industry. With advanced predictive AI working to create targeted ads.  There is a parenting strategy that consists of giving choices to control children. Don’t say: “Put your shoes on!”, say: “Do you want to put your left or your right shoe on first?” It’s called a false dichotomy when used in dialog, it’s a logical fallacy that people fall for. We see it being used in politics all the time as well as in advertising and marketing. And in the media.  Think about your breathing. You are free to breath however you want, but you rarely actually do it. Based on the air, your emotional state, physical state and so on, you will breathe differently without even necessarily noticing it. The rest of your behavior is like that too. You can control the way you walk if you want, but most of the time, you don't really think about it.  We design a lot of life around that. It’s not enough to explain to someone how to ride a bicycle, or a car, and then have them try to consciously control their body to turn the wheel, and press on the pedal and so on. People train a little bit, so that they can know how to do it as a reflex, a built in pattern, without needing to think. Martial arts are like that too. You train and train and train, because you know you are not going to have the luxury of thinking about your every move, you want to already know how to do the techniques and have done them so much that if you see an opening, you can react almost instantly, with as little actual time for thinking as possible. Other sports too. A basketball player shooting is not consciously thinking about their finger and elbow movements during the throw, they could tape it and analyze it later. But they train a lot, to be able to do it with muscle memory and trained reflexes.  So much of your life is like the organ donation opt-in vs opt-out issue. You technically can make a choice, but in practice, the way the environment is set up heavily influences your decision. The act of making a choice itself has a cost, and so there is a bias towards the default choice presented to you. People are meddling with your environment. Trillions of dollars are spent on teams of scientists, engineers, marketers, advertisers, etc, All to influence the choices you will make. They say that since you still have a choice, you are free, and so it doesn’t matter if they set up the system to be opt-in or opt-out. Are you really free, or is it a lie? A half-truth used as a distraction maybe.

Are we really free? Let's think about this for a moment. Are we truly free? Able to exercise our free will and achieve whatever we want to? First you have to think about what society demands for you. There's expectations and rules. There's norms and sacred mores to consider. That's a lot of idealistic pressures right there. And how about that Government? The individuals who make policies and laws. The ones who lead us and divide up the power and the money. Then there's every individuals own unique biology and personal circumstances to factor in. Are you morally sound and physically healthy? Are you mentally stable? Or predisposed to diseases or a mood disorder? Are you able to access the necassites? Food, water and medicines? Are you fortunate enough to drive a vehicle to your chosen occupation? Or are struggling to make the ends meet and keep your sanity in check? In my opinion I'm one the freest person I know of. I embrace who am and I'm not bond to a household or a automobile. I'm not even working so there's no management to piss off now. While most people scoff at my decision to not be a slave to the money or to any man. I am able to pick up everything I hold dear in just three bags and walk away. I respect myself, I understand that I'm accountable for my actions. I will respect you as well and I rarely judge anyone by their mistakes. I'm fallible too. Probably more than most. I suppose yes-I'm free. And I have to wonder how many people out there right now feel the same way about their lives. Hopefully-many do!

We are constrained by the laws of physics, of course. We cannot levitate or walk through walls or anything of the sort. We are free generally to do what we like while understanding that there are consequences for all actions. I can walk off the edge of a tall building, for instance. The understanding is that I will subsequently be subject to the force of gravity and the impact will very likely kill me. I’m quite free to threaten the life of the president, understanding that I will very likely be hauled in and questioned sharply by the Secret Service and very likely jailed. I can constantly ignore the traffic laws with the understanding that I will likely receive citations from the police or be involved in accidents. Nothing will physically prevent me from doing any of these things, nor any number of good things either. I can freely give away percentages of my income to charity, spend hours doing volunteer work, or help little old ladies across the street. My motives may be entirely altruistic or entirely selfish. There is no constraint either way. Most of the arguments I hear about the very contentious idea of “free will” are religiously informed and as such, nonsense. “If God knows our ultimate fate how can there be free will?” How indeed. Simple answer… There is no God. Our ultimate fate is determined either by our own actions or by actions that we have no control over. Free will does not come into play if a comet falls on my head tomorrow. The other view is more of a philosophical one that goes something like this: “The universe is subject to the laws of nature and thus will play out in a manner determined by those laws. Every event or action affects future actions. If one could extrapolate from original events, one could plot the exact fate of everything.” Cute idea, but the sheer “indeterminancy” of the Universe makes any such calculation essentially impossible. The final notion I’ll mention comes from the realm of neuroscience. It’s been discovered that the subconscious mind does a great deal of “processing”, and that many (if not all) decisions we make are made subconsciously and that these decisions “filter up” to the conscious mind that then fools itself into thinking that it made the decision. This would seem to indicate that we are but “meat puppets” that are being driven by our own subconscious minds. However: I’d argue that this is rather preliminary research and further that the subconscious is of necessity OUR subconscious, formed by our life experiences and heritage and culture and thus is a “singular” subconscious… Ours alone.

Short answer is -  No, We are not free. Now depending on what you mean by "free", there could be a different interpretation to it. There is one Absolute freedom, and then there is this relative freedom. and We do have some relative freedom. But no Absoulte freedom. In no way, shape or form we are absolutely free. We are governed (for a lack of better word) by so many rules and laws - both from social and physical world. Our physical world has some very specific set of rules which can not be broken. The laws of physics govern this Universe of ours - where nothing can go faster than the speed of light. So there is limit to everything. You can not jump higher than a certain height. You can not escape gravity without external help. You can not go to outer space on your own without any help. This limits prohibits any absolute freedom. You do have free will - but that is also more of a illusion. Think of sex - how easily you get attracted to it. Can you escape - for real for every single time it tries to get you in its grip. So if sex can enslave you, you are not free. Do you do anything that's out of the world - if not then you are only following the things from the world around you - that's not freedom. Our social world of course has many rules and laws -so you cant be going out and about and doing anything as you wish - so your freedom is limited by those set of rules. So this freedom we enjoy is relative freedom. We are not completely free in that sense but that has never been a problem to us mankind.  We enjoy life - within the boundaries of our social and physical world - there is so much to do and achieve that we can completely feel free without being bothered by what governs us as whole.

I think I know what you mean but still I wonder, who says that we are free? Or ever were free? And free of what? It really depends on your definitions, your circumstance, and how you scope the extent of "freedom". The answer in any case will be individual, relative and subjective. In my opinion, anyway.  Everything we see and do, even the culture we are born into, is filtered through our minds and interpreted individually. In that way, arguably, even seeming absolutes are in some way subjective. You may attempt to seek and test for absolute objective ethical neutrality, indeed I encourage you do exactly that, but it does tend to slip out of your grasp just when you think you have it. I always think of the punishment of  Tantalus here. An ancient Greek story of good and evil, proving perhaps that this search for absolute values is not just a modern one.      The short answer is that we use our personal value system to differentiate right from wrong. It is always subjective, at least to my mind, being based not on objective values or even absolutes but subjective, relative values chosen by you, consciously or not, from an array of options. Yes, our decisions are informed by our culture, true. And our culture is an inherited thing, developed subjectively over time by previous generations.  There's also an argument here over how much freedom and how many options we are allowed in any one society (it will vary), but unless we are totally controlled by others and have no say at all in our own lives, generally we do chose at least something. Even if not necessarily consciously!  There's another argument along the lines of innate values, being "values" that have been embedded in us by some process, be it by evolution or a spiritual methodology of your choosing. Again, we have problems of definition and of determining what is "innate".  I'll throw a few more ideas around to expand further on that answer.   Subjective = influenced by personal feelings, tastes or opinions. Objective = not influenced by personal feelings, tastes or opinions. Absolute = a value or principle held to be universally valid in and of itself. By extention, objective in nature. Relative = a value or principle without absolute validity that varies with perception and consideration. By extention, subjective in nature.   Are we really free? No. I can't say that currently we are free to do or be anything we can imagine, although that may change with future technology (such as virtualisation). More speculatively, others may see a spiritual dimension and/or opportunity here as well. Presently I can say that relative freedoms do apply, depending upon your definition of "free" and your individual context. As far as I can see, it has ever been so.  Does culture, advertisements, experiences etc shape us into who we are? Not entirely. These are certainly influences on 'who we are'. Depending upon your individual environmental context and personality you may or may not have choices. You may be able to modify or ignore your culture even by increments, or choose to avoid some experiences over others. There will be events outside of your choosing, yes. You may be able to avoid or mitigate advertising, too. Avoiding a broad "et cetera" is harder. You can't escape some features of your genome, for example. Ultimately, however, you process incoming neurological signals subjectively and personally.  Are these values subjective?  Yes, they are, in my opinion.  Assuming that you specifically mean good/evil and right/wrong then arguments arise as to how we can determine absolute, universal values without some reference to context, rendering the result relative and subjective. I suspect that ultimately all values are arguably subjective, at least by degree. The arguably more objective values are the physical and physiological ones, but even the ostensibly objective is individual, relative and personal, too. It's hard to escape the subjectivity clause I'm afraid, although obviously many have tried.      Then how do we differentiate right from wrong? Is differentiation dependent upon objectivity? No, not in my view. I believe that we can differentiate subjectively, indeed people do it every day. One way to do this is by having a personal value system, by which I mean an ethical and moral basis for making such decisions, and testing it regularly, widely and relatively against other examples. Decisions based not on well tested, consistent subjective values are valid, in my view. We all have a personal value system, influenced to varying degrees by the cultural, social, spiritual and contextual lives we lead. Our authenticity here remains intact if we maintain consistency with our regularly tested subjective values.   Then how do we differentiate good from evil? Do we need to? Is "evil" even a thing in and of itself? Or should we be recognising and differentiating behaviours based on our personal value system instead? And acting thereafter in accord with that value system.  This may or may not feel comfortable. Perhaps you would prefer absolute values for good/evil and right/wrong, I don't know. You could argue a case for that, of course, but our subjective minds will remain in charge of any one interpretation.     How restricted you feel by culture and commercialism depends a lot upon you and your relationship with your immediate environment. You may or may not feel free where you are, because of family or societal influences that close off degrees of freedom. But you may feel more free in another context, if you are lucky enough to be empowered to get there.   But in no sense can you achieve absolute objective freedom whilst living and breathing, especially freedom from personal decision making. (OK, maybe in a dream or altered reality? But still, there's an underlying dependency somewhere.) Reality's all relative and subjective as far as I can see.  Which doesn't mean that seeking and testing for absolute objective ethical neutrality is a waste of time, indeed it remains a noble pursuit, at least in my mind. Further reading:Noumenon - one possible absolute approachValue (personal and cultural) - what it is (one definition anyway)SubjectivityObjectivity (philosophy)David Hume

Americans like to brag about being in “the land of the free”… whenever I encounter that mindset I challenge an American to walk into an airport and shout “BOMB!”… they believe they have the freedom of speech… they don’t. We are living in a world where you are told you have the freedom to say what you want, believe in what you want… but say something “out of turn” and you can kiss your business, job, family, kids, relationships goodbye. Ask the many people who have stupidly said out loud what they think about this race, gender, people, sexual preference and a whole basket-load of other no-go topics. We BELIEVE we are free. More true however, is that we live in a glass prison … the walls are invisible to us until we get too close and feel the cold touch of the glass. Then shit really hits the fan… Even if you assume for a moment that government does not interfere in your thought, behaviour and practices, you still have to wake up every day to work and try to pile up savings for your old age. You can choose to just sit… but it will bite you later. You HAVE to report for duty. Have to fill in your tax returns. Have to pay your bills. [put long list of MUSTs, REQUIRED-TOs and HAVE-TOs here] The freest people are the ‘undiscovered’ freefolk (think GoT, Andaman, Amazon) who still roam free. NO bills. NO taxes. NO alimony. NO nothing… other than their basic survival needs and choices that nature dictates.

Freedom is the world is conditioned by several factors. That’s why we have freedoms, but not just freedom which represents being free from everything undesirable. In the world, we can be free from something while not free from something else. When free from something, this freedom is true so we’re truly free from that something. However, when not being free from other related things, we cannot say we’re truly free. For example, one is not in jail, but one’s brother is in jail. Although one is physically free from jail, one’s mind can be in jail with one’s brother - as one is bearing the burden of one’s brother being in jail. That is an example of how freedom is conditioned. Worldly freedoms are somehow connected. But they are not connected with total freedom or being free from all undesirable. For example, as one is not being in jail, one is free from confinement and punishment but one has to worry about other worldly things so one also wish to be free from these worldly undesirables that surround their victim. We have many problems with our minds and bodies. We have to look after them but we often don’t know how to look after our minds so they are usually not free, but confined by thoughts and they bear heavy loads. Relief is generally obvious when it happens. The heavier the load pressing the mind, the clearer the relief can be when it happens. That can be compared with walking on hot sands bear feet. When a feet is lifted up, it feels comfortable, but the other feet is very hot, so the feet with relief has to step on the hot sand again. Only when one gets to a true shade, one can really stand on cool sands. In deserts, animals like lizards run very fast, yet it has to run for shelter inside deep sand. As human beings, we can hardly get to the real shade like that. We just have to walk on the hot sands - day and night. We should say the total freedom is the true shade with cool sands - but we should not think it’s death.

Well, it depends on the context and definition of being free. Will you be free from the inevitability of death? Probably not anytime soon. Will you be free from the stresses of life? Nope. No matter how perfect of a family you have, or how much money you have, there’s always something to worry about. That’s just what the human mind is programmed to do. Worry. Will you be free to do what you want? Yes and no. You theoretically could go outside exposing your genitalia while doing Nazi salutes and talking about how the 3000 Americans who died on 9/11 deserved it, but after that, you would lose your freedom. At least in most places. You’ll never be free from emotion, unless you simply can’t feel it. Emotion can be a wonderful thing, or a horrible thing. Ultimately it depends on many things, short term and long term. You’ll never be free from imperfection. Honestly, there’s a lot you can be free from, all the way from student loans to happiness. Being free is a very subjective thing, because there are a million different ways to look at it.  This image has the context of being free applied to it, with the sunset, ocean, and wide arms. But they aren’t free from the sunburn, or how unrealistically large that sun is. In my own opinion, we can’t technically be free from anything. But if you’re happy and content with your life, that may count as free,

As it is phrased, this question is proving difficult for people to answer. That’s because it doesn’t provide us with any context. That is, it doesn’t specify in what regard one might be free—and there are many aspects in which freedom may or may not apply to a human being. This is a common problem with questions and answers on Quora: one word gets overworked as if it has only one definition and use. Then it seems it’s always my job to rotate things a quarter turn to reveal its other facets and put things in perspective. On Dictionary.com there are 36 entries for “free” under the “adjective” heading alone! Of course, not all may be considered attributes of people, but several may. And they can apply either physically, mentally, figuratively, or metaphysically, depending on what aspect of their being you have in mind. So, let’s single out some definitions and cite examples of how they might apply to human freedom.  enjoying personal rights or liberty, as a person who is not in slavery — This is pretty straightforward and I doubt any Reader would have a problem grasping the concept. I can legitimately say I live in a society where I’m “truly free” in this regard. Are all humans free in this way? No. But then the question doesn’t ask whether all humans are “truly free” in this or any other regard, does it? That’s a common fault in Quora questions: being too broad and vague in scope.  able to do something at will; at liberty — Again, there is no doubt I’m able to do something at will—of my own volition. Answering this question is one example of my having done something at my own will. Who can show that anyone or anything besides my own self has forced me to write this answer. There are any number of things I could have done during this time, yet I chose to write this answer. I submit that every other person on Quora has that written an answer has done so by this same freedom. Not everyone has the same freedom or the same means to write a Quora answer.  not occupied or in use — Since I’m free in the first since I mentioned and am therefore not a slave, I’m not in anyone’s use in that way. But I may or may not be free to be of voluntary use, to assist or serve someone else in some way. I many or may not be “free,” then, in the way often used in the British sitcom Are You Being Served?, where Mr. Peacock might ask another employee, “Mr. Humphries, are you free?” In the U.S. someone might ask, “Are you busy?” And, of course, not everyone in the world will be “free” (or busy) at the same time. But at any given moment, many very well are “free” or “busy.”  exempt or released from something specified that controls, restrains, burdens, etc. (usually followed by from or of) — This type of being “free” has the context almost built into it, in that it’s often followed by from or of—directly tying it to some constraint. The examples given after the definition are free from worry and free of taxes. Again, which of us can’t possibly be either of those at some point in our lives? And, though none of us is likely to be free from worry the entirety of our lives, does that prevent us from being “truly free” from worry at any time or for a given duration?  unimpeded, as motion or movement; easy, firm, or swift — Is the Reader tied or duck taped to a chair at this moment? Or, are you in a jail cell? In either case, you might be rightly deemed as not being “truly free” in that regard. But, what if you’re outside in a large open field? Are you “truly free”? Are you “free” at all? You can run in any direction. You can turn cartwheels. Or you can sit or lie on the grass. Who decides whether you are or are not “truly free”? What prevents you from designating yourself “free” by this definition? Let’s say you’re in that field as part of a prison detail. Are you still “free”? Is it not apparent that your being “free” (or not) depends entirely on which aspect of your being is in effect, and on who is considering that aspect? Who gets to arbitrate this, and for whom?  So, What Is the Question Again? Hopefully, the Reader begins to see that anyone presuming to answer for everyone the question of whether you are “free” is appropriating to himself some kind of omnipotent prerogative he or she obviously doesn’t possess. What, then, are we really asking here? It it even an answerable question? There’s no set context or perspective by which a useful answer can be tended. Every answer can only be the Writer’s personal opinion or philosophy. Which accomplishes what, exactly? You think being “free” is this, and I think it’s that. Or, you think there’s a difference between being “truly free” and I think “truly” mitigates absolutely nothing (which I indeed do). But, once all our verdicts are in—then what? What have we accomplished? Have we resolved anything? Wait—maybe there is something. We’ve all gotten in some writing practice. We’ve all had an opportunity to show off our writing (and, perhaps, thinking) skills. Some of us may even have taken this opportunity to make some kind of point about doing such exercises—even suggesting there is none, except they’ve actually participated in the exercise and therefore sound like some kind of hypocrite or smartass for even participating. Who knows? Who would do such a thing, anyway? Maybe its simply human nature and narcissism, and generating views and more visibility for ourselves. For some, tons of upvotes. Then again, maybe some do it just because they’re “truly free” to do so.  "Meaningless! Meaningless!" says the Teacher. "Utterly meaningless! Everything is meaningless." — Eccl 1:2  Related: Johnnie Lockett's answer to Is human consciousness only an artifact of electrochemical processes in the human brain? No, but true freedom is not what people think it is. True freedom is anarchy - total absence of rules. BUT, you're wrong again as you can be free. Everything you said was wrong, although I'll start at the bottom as it were. You may not be able to become a recording artist, but you can still do music for the love of it. You can record it and put it on Youtube or busk or any number of other things. Your ability or inability to get a contract is a meeting of your freedom to try and their freedom to accept or deny you. Freedom isn't compelling other people to do what you want. This is your freedom, yes, if you devote all your energy to music and can't make a living out of it then you may starve but once again, the freedom is choosing to make the attempt. Likewise, you and I have complete freedom to commit crimes. We can make the attempt - others will use their freedoms to try and stop you. The government will try and punish you based on the laws that it wants you to live under. I fully acknowledge that plenty of people will say that I'm getting it wrong and that there being consequences means that I don't have freedom but even if you were in a paradise where your sustenance needs require only that you reach out and take it you are still restricted by the physical laws. People still have the right to not want to listen to your music, unless you're the only one with freedom.

Reminds one of Rousseau's saying, 'Man is born free, but everywhere he is in chains'. For Rousseau the condition of not being free (being 'all against all', i.e. the condition of humanity in the 'state of nature' as described by Thomas Hobbes, but with very different implications) necessitated a 'social contract'. Well, in the Western world we are all likely persuaded that, as stated by Churchill, democracy is the lesser evil, better than every other political arrangement. Are the wealthy, the millionaires, or simply well-to-do - given an absence of war and/or general turmoil, really free? The answer is simple and everyone knows it: they enjoy a relative freedom (denominated 'negative freedom'), provided also there is marital harmony, absence of disease, etc.; this fortunate lot may still have all sorts of worries, grudges, and unfulfilled desires. In reality, there can only be PSYCHOLOGICAL freedom, even in the presence of physical pain and/or discomfort. For that to be the case, you have to observe, and accomplish, the Oracle's dictum (Oracle of Delfos): Gnothi seautón, 'know thyself'. I will not tell you here how to do it or go about it.

Oh, I love this question. I follow the principal that we are free to make any choice we wish. The reason we generally choose one option over another is simply because we prefer the consequences of that choice than the consequences of the other. Or it’s an easier choice to make. Let’s use an example. I can choose between a red apple and a green apple. If I choose the green apple, nothing will happen to me. If I choose the red apple I will die. Dramatic but you get the idea. Now obviously I choose the green apple because I don’t want to do. The question remains, did I freely make that choice considering the outcomes. Yes, I did. The idea of freedom is that if I wanted to I could still choose that red apple. So long as I still have the ability to choose that red apple, no matter the obstacles, limitations and consequences, I’ve still got freedom of choice. The issue with freedom is when an external body begins making the choice harder to make. To add to my example, imagine the government imposed a ban on every red apple. So now it’s harder to get my hands on that red apple. Finally I find one but it’s locked deep in a building, guarded heavily by dogs and barbed wire. I still have the freedom to choose to eat that apple but that freedom is being encroached upon by an external force. So long as we always have that ability to make the choice, so long as we have choice, we have freedom.

Do you realize how many choices you make every day? I have never tried to count them as there are just too many. From the simple to the complex, we make thousands of choices every day. We are indeed free to make these choices. Is this the freedom referred to in the question, probably not. Not all humans are free depending on their geographical location or the culture in which they live their lives. In certain country’s, if you don’t follow the laws of the government you could be put to death. In certain cultures if you don’t abide by that cultures rules and traditions, you could be banished and considered dead and in some cases actually put to death. That isn’t being free. In a place like any country that claims to be a free country, Like the USA, there are laws to be followed, and if you choose you can break those laws and risk being caught and suffer the consequences. Some of these consequences aren’t as severe as they probably should be but certainly not as severe as they might be in a country or place that isn’t considered to be free. True freedom therefore comes in the God given freedom to do what is right. Freedom to bless and heal instead of harm and hurt, freedom to love instead of hate, freedom to do things to help others and maybe save lives instead of take advantage of others or even take their lives, freedom to Worship the One and Only God who gave you this freedom. That is true freedom.

It is a natural tendency of every human being to want to be free. Freedom is not luxury, it is a necessity. Not just human beings, but even animals want freedom. Babies want freedom. If you tie a scarf on the neck of a baby, it just wants to remove it. You put a chain on a baby’s neck and the baby will want to pull it out. It is the adults who put jewelry around their neck, but children want freedom, they don’t want any restriction. That is why they throw their hands up and down… free!Wanting freedom is innate to human beings as well as animals. Every life wants freedom, and liberation or moksha is nothing but freedom. Freedom is a natural desire in every human being but when the mind gets so muddled up in unnecessary day to day things, it forgets that it wants freedom. It is as good as someone who wants to sleep but has forgotten how to sleep. What does it mean to be free? Freedom is not running away from situations and circumstance. Sometimes a situation is stifling or unpleasant, and we run away from it and think this is what freedom is, but that is not so. Freedom means: Being unphased by circumstances, situations and the people around youBeing free from your own emotional garbageBeing free from the jungle of your thoughts that bother youBeing free from all the entanglement that you harbor in your headBeing free from fear and anxietyAnything that stifles you and makes you feel small, being free from that is what freedom is. How to move towards freedom? Let go of cravings and aversionsWhether you accept it or not, watch it or not, life is an act of letting go. It started the moment you were born. You let go of the womb and came into this world. As soon as you came here, you started breathing in and breathing out and you are taking food in and letting it out. It is a constant exchange. There is a big blind spot in the discussion of the free will of freedom in general. Freedom is ALWAYS relative to the subject whose freedom we are talking about. The idea of ‘absolute freedom’ is irrelevant. It has nothing to do with any existing creature in the Universe. We cannot even think what ‘absolute freedom’ could mean in practice as ‘practice’ imposes the limitations of the real world to any creature dwelling in the real world. Like gravity and other laws of physics and chemistry We can talk about freedom meaning ‘not a subject of external restraint’ which means that there is no state official or aggressive gang member telling you how to behave. Being rich offers more degrees of freedom than poverty. Being sick naturally limits one’s freedom but so does stupidity.If you are not capable of making your way in the modern complicated society, you feel that society is limiting your well-being even though it is the discrepancy between your abilities and the demands of everyday life. The liberty of a human being is always related to the subject itself.Our very biology keeps us from breathing underwater or flying without external appliances or machines. We cannot read minds, we cannot teleport. Even telekinesis is beyond our reach. The real world is where we live. Some philosophers seem to forget this.

However, there will always be constraints on our ability to successfully carry out our willed plan. Constraints such as:- Basic laws of physics (Gravity - not just a good idea. It's the law!)- Social bounds (strictures) and levels of tolerance of "aberrant" behaviour- Extant hierarchical social power structures. Yes, these can usurped at great cost, but it is guaranteed (by thermodynamically optimizing social logic) that another hierarchical power structure will take the place of the one you usurped. Ok you could be on top of the new social hierarchy. But if you are the leader and think you are free, you are sadly deluded. You will conform to the norms and limits;  the characteristic behaviour expected of good leaders, or you will be done like dinner soon enough. So in short, we are free to dream, and if our dream is within social and physical bounds, we may be free to realize our dream, but if not, then our flight is confined to our fancy.
